Posts.Content: Hi star67.  It is a lot to think about at once, you are right there! Thanks for the hugs, they're much needed at the moment. I didn't think I'd feel like this after it quietened down, I expected to bounce back and feel fine. I suppose it all takes time. I hope you get the answers you need. Hugs back Aimee xx
Posts.Title: Zoladex and tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: Thanks for the reply and the link Kacang.  It's very confusing isn't it! What worries me more is that since looking into it more I can't find anything that really shows any evidence to support using the two together. There must be something, but finding the info I want is proving difficult. It seems that everyone knows what they do but not why they are used together or the reasoning behind the time they are given for.  Thanks for your help. I hope you are well x
Posts.Title: Zoladex and tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: Hi jowoomot,  Wow that must have been a bit of a rollercoaster! I hated the waiting to see about the treatments, hopefully your December test will be good news. I just don't understand the time scales of it all. I am 33 and obviously not near menopause so I understand the need to suppress the ovaries but why 2 years when my tamoxifen is 10 years? It all seems a bit weird. I'm eager to stop the Zoladex due to the side effects, but it's hard trying to weigh up the pros and cons when the information I have been given seems a bit vague.  That said I know we are all lucky to have the health care system we have and access to medications like we do, I really don't want to come across as ungrateful, I just don't think there's enough explanation of our treatments. I see my oncologist next week, I've only met her once before and this is my signing off appointment, so I'm going armed with a lot of questions! Let us know how you get on in December, fingers crossed!  Xx
Posts.Title: Zoladex and tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: Hi Star67, I read something the other day, it was about how in other countries where people pay for medical services they sometimes prescribe zoladex short term to women who are unsure of having hysterectomies so that they can experience menopause before deciding. Obviously for them they do it from a cost perspective so women can it a sense try the menopause before they buy it. But perhaps in your case this might help you decide where to go from here? I'll let you all know what my oncologist says about it all. Just realised it's not until the 6th that I see her ....then got my 3rd Zoladex booked for the day after xx
Posts.Title: Zoladex and tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: Hi Anni69, thanks for your reply. How are you finding the tamoxifen so far? Isn't it strange how each oncologist has a different view of things? Mine was adamant that it is protocol to have both tamoxifen and Zoladex with a hormone receptive cancer. I'm not sure I'll ever fully understand what I'm taking or why, I'm just blindly following at the moment.  I'm due to see my oncologist next week so I think I'm going to write some questions to ask. I think it's my signing off appointment and to say I'm worried is an understatement. It seems that all the support you need is there during surgery and treatment, but things don't really hit you until after the storm and then you're on your own.  Sorry I sound really pessimistic, having a down day and need to give myself a shake I think xx
Posts.Title: Zoladex and tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: Hi Anni69, thanks for your reply. How are you finding the tamoxifen so far? Isn't it strange how each oncologist has a different view of things? Mine was adamant that it is protocol to have both tamoxifen and Zoladex with a hormone receptive cancer. I'm not sure I'll ever fully understand what I'm taking or why, I'm just blindly following at the moment.  I'm due to see my oncologist next week so I think I'm going to write some questions to ask. I think it's my signing off appointment and to say I'm worried is an understatement. It seems that all the support you need is there during surgery and treatment, but things don't really hit you until after the storm and then you're on your own.  Sorry I sound really pessimistic, having a down day and need to give myself a shake I think xx
Posts.Title: Zoladex and tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: Hi anni69, I can definitely relate to what you've said. I think that from the moment of diagnosis we are placed on a conveyer belt and passed through so many things that we don't have time to digest what is happening to us and the reality of what we are dealing with. It's not until things slow down that it hits us. I've been struggling with this too and have started seeing a counsellor.  I worked all the way through everything and only took a little time off for my surgery (lumpectomy and sentinel node removal), now I've finished radiotherapy and have had to take time off work as I no longer feel physically or mentally capable of doing much. I think this is probably normal, it is a lot to go through, but I think to outsiders it must seem very strange that it's only now that it sets in. Since going off sick I've been let go from my job and so that as well is worrying me. It was hard enough feeling the pressure to get better and return to a job that I knew without the stress of trying to find new employment! Try to be kind to yourself and allow yourself to grieve. It's definitely part of the process of coming to terms with everything you've been through. You are strong and you will feel better. Huge hugs xx
Posts.Title: Zoladex and tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: Sorry this question has probably been asked a million times before, can anyone tell me why Zoladex is used as well as tamoxifen? I understand what it does, I just don't understand why I've been told I will need it for two years and tamoxifen for 10 years. I'm 3 months into tamoxifen and 2 months into Zoladex. The tamoxifen gave me very few side effects, the Zoladex however is a nightmare. I really would like to come off it but since finishing radiotherapy mid October I've not really had any contact from oncologist and bcn and I'm unsure who I can talk to.  I was given the impression that I'm on my own from here until the standard routine check ups. Any help or advice would be greatly appreciated xx
Posts.Title: Zoladex and tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: Thanks for the reply and the link Kacang.  It's very confusing isn't it! What worries me more is that since looking into it more I can't find anything that really shows any evidence to support using the two together. There must be something, but finding the info I want is proving difficult. It seems that everyone knows what they do but not why they are used together or the reasoning behind the time they are given for.  Thanks for your help. I hope you are well x
Posts.Title: Zoladex and tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: Hi Star 67, thanks for your reply. How do you feel about it all? I read up on other people's experiences also before starting. All I can say is that it seems everyone is different. I've found tamoxifen to be fine, very few side effects and I still felt like me. Others I've spoken to have had mixed emotions about it. Zoladex is the same, some people are fine on it but personally I really started struggling when Zoladex was added. Perhaps it's the combination of the two together? But I've gone from feeling like a happy, confident 33 year old woman to feeling like I'm ancient. I suppose it's a big change and a shock to the system though when we thrust our bodies into menopause before they are naturally ready.  I hope your treatment goes well xx
